title: Eagles defensive tackle Fletcher Cox 'needed a shotgun to stop a bat-wielding intruder
text:
Philadelphia Eagles defensive tackle Fletcher Cox was recently forced to grab a shotgun for protection as a bat-wielding intruder attempted to force his way into the NFL star's New Jersey home in pursuit of his ex-girlfriend.

According to court documents obtained by Philadelphia's WPVI, the incident occurred around midnight on October 15 when Corbyn Nyemah arrived at Cox's house and attempted to break in by throwing rocks at the front door. Surveillance cameras reportedly witnessed Nyemah circling the house with a baseball bat and making several attempts to gain access through the garage.

Upon hearing the intruder, Cox reportedly grabbed his shotgun and called police.

Nyemah then fled in his Porsche SUV, but was eventually captured by U.S. Marshals.

Philadelphia Eagles defensive tackle Fletcher Cox was recently forced to grab a shotgun for protection as a bat-wielding intruder attempted to force his way into the NFL star's New Jersey home in pursuit of his ex-girlfriend. Corbyn Yeman (pictured, right, outside the Eagles' Lincoln Financial Field in South Philadelphia) was arrested later and hit with a restraining order

WPVI's Chad Pradelli confirmed much of the criminal complaint with Nyemah himself

He has since posted bond and confirmed much of the criminal complaint WPVI, saying that he believed he wanted to speak with his ex-girlfriend under the belief that they had been rekindling their relationship.

Nyemah reportedly damaged the woman's car, which was parked outside the 28-year-old Cox's home.

A temporary restraining order has been filed, requiring Nyemah to stay away from his former girlfriend. WPVI reported that Nyemah texted his ex-girlfriend a picture of himself brandishing a firearm after being pursued by police.

According to NJ.com, Nyemah was charged with burglary, two counts of criminal mischief and resisting arrest. He is expected to be in court later this month.

Cox's house reportedly suffered $2,000 worth of damages.

Surveillance cameras reportedly witnessed Nyemah circling Cox's house (pictured) with a baseball bat and making several attempts to gain access through the garage

Eagles coach Doug Pederson decline to address the issue at Wednesday's practice, in which Cox was absent.

'The police are handling it,' Pederson told reporters. 'It's a personal issue, so I'm out of it.'

Pederson did say that the team will look into additional security measures.

'As far as a security issue, we look into it,' Pederson said. 'Obviously the police get involved. From that standpoint I can't do anything other than hear the results of the investigation and what comes out of that.

'Obviously we do the best to protect our players here on premise but obviously they have personal lives, we all have personal lives, so we do the best we can to educate our players and try to protect them the best we can.'

Drafted out of Mississippi in the first round of the 2012 NFL Draft, Cox has established himself as one of the premiere interior defensive lineman in the NFL. The Super Bowl champion is also a four-time Pro Bowl selection.
